review_title: Care assistant for people with mental health disabilities.
pros: Some of the people I cared for were okay to care for.
cons: The hours were too long, plus the work was non exercisable and tyring with lack of activity.

job_title: Activities Assistant in Basildon, South East England, England
pros: Supportive team and head office staff, friendly great work environment
cons: No room for growth or moving up in role. If you are poorly and cant not continue your role, the changes the company can facilitate are small and can be let go.

pros: Rewarding and good to be a part of a customers journey
cons: The Click - family and friends

pros: Lots of hours if you want overtime
cons: Basic pay rate, so staff leave the company creating staff shortage a lot

pros: Teaching new skills and providing structured support within the Adult disability learning sector.
cons: Inconsistent rules and policy enforcement by management, biased favouritism of key staff members which allows and ignores serious policy breaches without consequence. Workplace bullying and dismissal of whistle blowers. Vindictive persecution of all who challenge managerial decisions. Rules and internal policies often flouted by staff who are favourites, creating a hostile work environment. High staff turnover due to unfair/biased workload expectations, extreme psychological, physical anxiety and exhaustion.

pros: Working from home making a difference to participant
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Employment Coach/Workshop Facilitator in Huntingdon, England
pros: Great place to work - disability aware
cons: None - really great place to work

pros: Great staff and management friendly
cons: Contracted only may get extended

pros: a very very good employer
cons: nothing negative about this employer

pros: All staff work in the design hub as a team. At every level, everyone is committed to doing the very best for Papworth customers. Its a good feeling doing a job that benefits others.
cons:
Low wages. No career prospects. Without a doubt the expectation is not  reflected in the salary. There is little understanding by senior staff of the design technician's role  within HIA. A DT needs knowledge of the built environment- construction, design Building regulations, planning law as well as being able use a variety of CAD software.  
There is little opportunity for career development through relevant training.
Poor working conditions in the design hub. Dismal building, no space to break out, We feel like a poor relation to the Cambridge head office.

review_title: A charity that has lost it's way
pros: Flexible employer, well paid if you are back office or management, lovely colleagues.
cons:
A distinct lack of leadership qualities at the top which was not fixed in the 5+ years I was there means the organisation lurches forward with no real direction and no solution to the many problems it has.  These are mostly easy fixes and there are lots of eager people ready to do it - but it is blocked by Leadership.
There is a complete disconnect between beneficiaries and management
Front line staff are massively undervalued and underpaid.
No development opportunities and no value placed on hard working, passionate people.

pros: Great Flexi-time policy for head office roles, nice colleagues.
cons: A lot of change went on in time that I was there with re-structures (which were needed) following the appointment of a new CEO, unfortunately this was at the cost of the culture and ethos of the charity. The leadership from the top didn't deliver what was needed, leaving middle management struggling and frustrated. Standard third sector inefficiencies and poor decision making/ delivery.

review_title: Not the place for people with disabilities
pros: The hard working staff who try to continue to do the right thing despite the horrible working conditions.
cons: Behind the positive messages is corporate bullying worse than I have ever seen. Senior staff have no idea about disability fairness. Witnessed disabled staff discriminated against and bullied. The CEO has run the trust into serious debts. No idea how they are allowed to get away with it.

pros: Varied shifts which Management try to work around your preferences as much as possible.  Can be busy, but equally, occasionally you get an easier shift.  Personally rewarding job knowing you are helping people to live as independently as possible.
cons: If short staffed you may end up with some shifts that are not the most convenient for you.

pros: Working with disabled and disadvantaged people to help them back to work again. Great committed people to work with.
cons: Poor environment, no training strategy, poor salaries, management more worried about targets than the people they were there to help

pros: supportive, enthusiastic, friendly, great rewards, opportunities, training.
cons: Can be stressful at times - but what job can't!

job_title: Youth Support Worker in Papworth Everard, England
pros: The trust works hard to make a real difference to people's lives. Therefore, jobs with this organisation provide great job satisfaction.
cons: No cons - I really enjoyed working for this Trust.

pros: A workplace where everyone is friendly and always there for you.

cons: Working for a job agency was not a permanent position.
